Thanks @GaryMarcus! I like to frame my worries in a constructive way. Cognitive theories of human decision making and well designed AI governance, risk assessment, and tools, done with a multi-stakeholder approach, are promising to get to value-aligned AI.

@amolk We characterize fast solvers as relying only on experience and not reasoning about the problem instance. This usually makes the computationally faster. Their confidence level is used by the metacognitive agent to decide whether to adopt their solution or activate a slow solver.

@hyonschu @GaryMarcus A comprehensive view of our architecture for thinking fast and slow in AI, with experimental results for grid navigation: https://t.co/cdpQk4txtu #thinkingfastandslowinAI #metacognition
@hyonschu @GaryMarcus See our approach here: https://t.co/eHt3hU2cyW

@hyonschu @GaryMarcus I would argue that metacognition has some features of System 1 and some of System 2. In our project the metacognitive agent has a first phase which is (kind of) System 1 and a (possible) second more computationally complex phase which is System 2.

@GaryMarcus I agree. Data-driven approaches are System 1, while reasoning is System 2. We need both. My work keeps them separate and decide which one to use by metacognition. There may be other approaches, but so far I did not see much reasoning from data-driven AI. #thinkingfastandslowinAI

@DrJasBerry @GaryMarcus @verge I agree about the team effort. I also appreciated the visibility given to the team on stage.

@chubicki Thanks for your thoughts on Optimus. Very clear and useful to understand and compare its physical capabilities and the team‚Äôs challenges. However, I would like to know more also about its cognitive capabilities, which were not really mentioned nor shown in yesterday‚Äôs demo.

@JrKibs @GaryMarcus @cwty Many people have already worked on all these challenges for decades. What is innovative here? The methods, the results, the goal? It cannot just be done to ‚Äúgo somewhere interesting and not boring‚Äù.
@GaryMarcus @verge For my roboticists friends: is Optimus better than state of the art robot dexterity and navigation capabilities? Is it using innovative solutions to current robotics challenges?

@GaryMarcus @cwty They only talked about physical and navigational capabilities. Nothing about decision making, reasoning, and problem solving. What are these robots going to be useful for? Same tasks as a self-driving car? And if so, why do they need to be humanoid?

Make sure you submit your work to this track!
@TrendsCognSci @ShannonVallor @tonyjprescott @JFBonnefon @brain_on_dance Thanks all for the great chat!

@tonzani @TrendsCognSci Of course, but the combination with AI brings new/expanded challenges. The evolution of the AI ethics flied can help accelerate the neuroethics path. Fortunately neurotech is behind AI in terms of application at scale: we can learn from AI ethics to anticipate and address issues.
@TrendsCognSci 10 years is a very long time, considering how much this field has changes in the past few years.

@TrendsCognSci AI is increasingly being used with other technologies, for example neurotech. This brings new and expanded ethics challenges. I think the field needs to expand the scope to include embedded AI scenarios.
@JFBonnefon @ShannonVallor @TrendsCognSci I agree: people often see this in the MM experiment but the authors and the papers clearly said that this is not what they did nor the intent.

@TrendsCognSci For corporations: concrete methodologies for developers, software tools, education/training, diverse teams, adoption and incentives frameworks, integration with existing processes (like security by design and privacy by design).

@JFBonnefon @TrendsCognSci I would say that this is part of "global explainability", that describes in general why an AI system behaves in a certain way. Local explainability refers to the reason for a specific decision.

@brain_on_dance @TrendsCognSci I would say we need (at least) transparency and  explainability to achieve a system of trust. Fairness work is needed but sometimes (because of intersectionality for example) it may not be possible to eliminate all bias, so we need to have transparency.

@ShannonVallor @JFBonnefon @TrendsCognSci These two are very different experiments. MM was just collecting and analysing data, without making any decisions or recommendation based on the data. AD is making judgements, and sometimes in a clearly biased way.
@tonzani @JFBonnefon @TrendsCognSci Education is very important, but it needs to be based on transparency by those that deploy these robots.

@TrendsCognSci One specific issue is the appearance of these robots, that may induce people to think they are more capable or "intelligent" than what they really are. It is very important to be transparent about the real capabilities and limitations of an AI system.
@JFBonnefon @TrendsCognSci I agree. The Moral Machine data collection experiment allowed us to see how values and priorities change over cultures and geographical areas.
@brain_on_dance @TrendsCognSci Of course! Active engagement is essential.

@TrendsCognSci The Global Partnership on AI is a collection of 20+ governments (in US, Canada, Europe, Asia, ...) that want to address AI challenges together, also considering the cultural differences, although based on similar values.
@ShannonVallor @JFBonnefon @TrendsCognSci An additional reason to have human-machine teams, rather than autonomous systems.

@JFBonnefon @TrendsCognSci I don't think it can be done only with logic-based AI, or only with learning from data. It needs both. Logic-based AI is important also for explainability reasons and human-AI meaningful collaboration.
@ShannonVallor @TrendsCognSci This to me implies that we need to use both logic-based AI and machine learning.
@JFBonnefon @brain_on_dance @ShannonVallor @TrendsCognSci A risk-based approach can help, but it is important to define what risk is (like to human rights, values, and freedoms).
@tonyjprescott @brain_on_dance @TrendsCognSci Human-centric may leave out animals and planet. I would be more inclusive.

@TrendsCognSci Ethically-relevant outcomes are also in contexts with non-autonomous machines, like decision support systems that recommend decisions. A possible context is augmenting the decision capabilities of professionals in many domains, such as HR, healthcare,  and financial systems.
@TrendsCognSci Machine ethics has evolved a lot in recent years. In particular, AI ethics has gone through various phases: awareness, issues identification, principles, policies, practice.
@ShannonVallor @TrendsCognSci I agree with Shannon on the interpretation of machine ethics.
